subNodes.conversationText:
A pale man in rich livery, his long hair pulled back with a ribbon, was studying the ground.

"Ah-ha!" he cried suddenly and swooped down to pick up a loose leaf of yellowed paper. Then he noticed and took a step back.
"Are you mad, or are you dangerous?"

"Good, good!" said the man, brushing off the paper he'd picked up. "I've passed through these woods many times, and they've never been as bad as this -- malicious fairies at every turn, bandits, strange people doing strange things..." He glanced at the normal gourd that Knott had once again become. It lay at <FirstName>'s feet.
It looked like a page from an old calendar. At the top was written "Januarie, Month of the Beggar." Below the writing was an image.

A beggar was trying to run through twilight and deep snow while three skinny wolves pulled at his cloak. A candle glowed in the window of a far-off house, but the door was locked, <FirstName> knew. The old woman who lived there was deaf and suspicious. Her window's light seemed as remote as the cold stars above the scene.
"Strange," murmured <FirstName>, looking away from the illustration. "For a moment, I felt as if I were really there."

The man peered at the page inquisitively, first right-side up and then upside-down.

"If you say so."
"Anyhow, I had all the pages of this calendar until -- well, until I lost them. But that's a long story."

"Oh? Very well." He cleared his throat. "I have the honor of being the servant of an esteemed but eccentric person, a collector of oddities. Collecting for its own sake is irrational, but it is also my master's one true vocation; infer what you like from that."

"He sent me to fetch this calendar from the ruins of the great library of Xianaqash. How he knew about it or was so sure I'd find it exactly where he told me it'd be I have no idea. I have learned not to pry too deeply into his mysteries."
The young witch waited for him to continue.
"I was on my way back from Xianaqash when I was beset by wicked fairies. I thought they were going to kill me, but they only made fun of me, pulled my hair, and capered around."
"'What's this?' one said, taking the calendar from my satchel." The man was imitating the squealing voice of a redcap. "'A book full of time?'"
"Go on -- but the imitations are not necessary."
"The fairy grabbed the calendar. 'Don't take that,' I said. 'It's a present!' They seemed very childlike, so I thought this line of reasoning might persuade them."
"Indeed. 'All the more reason to take it,' the fairy said. "You take your present as you get it."
"'Time! So that's what this is. What's to be done with it?"

"'The only thing you can." At that, the lead fairy threw the calendar into the air. 

"Waste it!"

A great gust of wind, quite extraordinary, leapt up out of nowhere, ripping the calendar apart and sending the leaves flying in every direction.  Then the fairies turned into moths and flew away."

"What am I to do? The manuscript is -- was -- quite precious. My master will be sorely disappointed that all I have is January. But how can I find the rest? I can't spend days scouring perilous woods."
"That is exactly what I'm doing. I could keep an eye open for the rest of your calendar."

"Well, a friend of mine lives not far from the forest. I can stay with him for a few days and come back. If you find at least six of the lost pages, I'll give you something from my master's collection that might suit you." He looked meaningfully at Pharaoh. "I'm not a churchy sort of person. I don't mind helping witches."

They soon came to an agreement. Colin -- that was his name -- would wait at the forest gate next Thursday. "You know, the south entrance, where the trail leads to the road. The one with the old statue on the south edge of the woods," he told <FirstName>.

Then the two parted ways.

actions.a_parameter_1: THE ELEVEN MONTHS has been added to journal.

subNodes.conversationText: "Oh! Well -- in any case, if you happen to see any calendar leaves --"
The man nodded, and the two parted ways.

"Well, a friend of mine lives not far from the forest. I can stay with him for a few days and come back. If you find at least six of the lost pages, I'll give you something from my master's collection that might suit you." He looked meaningfully at Pharaoh. "I'm not a churchy sort of person. I don't mind helping witches."
"Perhaps I can hear a short version of it."

"My master is a collector of oddities, and the calendar this picture belonged to was one of them. I found it in Xianaqash and was returning to him from that desolate place when I was beset by fairies."

"They did no harm to me, but they destroyed the calendar. One of them grabbed it, threw it high in the air, and made a joke about time. A great wind picked up out of nowhere and scattered the pages far and wide."

"What am I to do? The manuscript is -- was -- quite precious. My master will be sorely disappointed that all I have is January. But how can I find the rest? I can't spend days scouring perilous woods."
The man nodded, and the two parted ways.
"Trickery? If you say so." He drew back the paper but kept it in hand.
The man barely glanced at the remarkable image.
"Anyhow, I had all the pages of this calendar until -- well, until I lost them. But that's a long story."
"I'm the servant of a most mercurial master. He sends me on errands, some of them very absurd. I'm returning to him now -- or I was," he said, looking at the paper in his hands.
"Take a look at this," he said, holding out the paper.
It looked like a page from an old calendar. At the top was written "Januarie, Month of the Beggar." Below the writing was an image.
"May your path out be easier. Farewell," said <FirstName>.
"May your path out be easier. Farewell," said <FirstName>.
The man nodded, and the two parted ways.
"But sane enough to own it. We're off to a better start than I've had with everyone else here."
"Well, I hope you don't mean me any harm. I don't have much to offer."

He brushed off the paper he'd picked up. "I've passed through these woods many times, and they've never been as bad as this -- malicious fairies at every turn, bandits, strange people doing strange things..." He glanced at the normal gourd that Knott had once again become. It lay at <FirstName>'s feet.
He laughed. "Oh, I suppose not. I'd rather you didn't."

He brushed off the paper he'd picked up. "I've passed through these woods many times, and they've never been as bad as this -- malicious fairies at every turn, bandits, strange people doing strange things..." He glanced at the normal gourd that Knott had once again become. It lay at <FirstName>'s feet.
"May your path out be easier. Farewell," said <FirstName>.
